security: Revealing that the CIA used the Lykes Steamship Company as a cover for its employees could damage the company's reputation and compromise current or future operations. The reference to CIA employees serving under commercial cover reveals sensitive operational methods: "Cover and Commercial Staff (CCS) files reveal that three CIA employees served under cover of the [Lykes Steamship] Company during all or part of the period 1962 through 1964."
summary: A memo from Arthur C. Close, Deputy Chief, Cover & Commercial Staff, to John Walker, regarding CIA relations with Lykes Steamship Company, noting that three CIA employees served under Lykes cover between 1962 and 1964.
summary_one_paragraph: In a memorandum dated May 21, 1976, Arthur C. Close, Deputy Chief of the Cover & Commercial Staff (CCS), informs John Walker about CIA relations with the Lykes Steamship Company. The memo indicates that CCS files showed three CIA employees using Lykes Steamship Company as cover during the period from 1962 to 1964. One officer was stationed abroad under Lykes cover from 1961 to 1968, another served from 1953 until July 1962 before taking a bona fide position with the company and later assisted the Agency as an intermittent source in Europe from 1964 to early 1967, and a third was placed with Lykes in the U.S. in 1961 for training but was withdrawn when an overseas assignment was cancelled.
title: CIA Relations with [Lykes Steamship] Company
